attributes.title: Meaning in Life and Resilience
attributes.description: Research suggests that people who experience their lives as meaningful have higher resilience to difficulties and are better able to cope with challenges encountered in daily life (Miao & Gan, 2018; Schaefer et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2007).  However, the precise mechanisms linking meaning in life to improved resilience and effective coping strategies are unknown.  These studies will investigate meaning in life's association with adaptive coping strategies in different contexts as well as probe potential mechanisms that account for these associations.

q1.value: Meaning in life and Coping with an Exam

q2.value: Sarah Ward, Jake Womick, Laura A. King, Milla Titova

q3.value: Research suggests that people who experience their lives as meaningful are better able to cope with challenges encountered in daily life (Miao & Gan, 2018; Schaefer et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2007).  Meaning in life is correlated with optimism and positive affect, which are also linked to improved coping. The present study aims to determine to what extent meaning in life, optimism, and positive affect are each independently related to coping appraisals (related to an exam taken in a class).

q4.value:
Time 1 refers to measures completed in the initial questionnaire (pre-exam). 
Time 2 refers to measures completed after the students’ exam. 
Adaptive appraisals refer to items assessing active coping, planning, positive reframing, worry/self-doubt/blame, and coping self-efficacy (at time 1) in relation to the upcoming exam. Time 2 adaptive appraisal measures will be briefer (only 11 items) and will primarily cover coping self-efficacy, worry/self-doubt and perceived exam performance. 


Meaning in life, optimism, and positive affect will be positively correlated. 

Adaptive appraisals at time 1 will be correlated with adaptive appraisals at time 2 (post-exam). Note that these are different items due to length constraints for time 2 measures.

Meaning in life will be positively associated with adaptive appraisals both at time 1 and time 2 (post-exam). 

Optimism will be positively associated with adaptive appraisals both at time 1 and time 2 (post-exam). 

Positive affect will be positively associated with adaptive appraisals both at time 1 and time 2 (post-exam). 

Meaning in life will be negatively associated with distressed emotions at time 2 (post-exam).

Optimism will be negatively associated with distressed emotions at time 2 (post-exam).

Optimism will account for the association between meaning in life and adaptive appraisals at times 1 and 2.

Optimism will account for the association between meaning in life and distressed emotions at time 2 (post-exam).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is an observational correlational study with two time points. Participants will be students in two different undergraduate psychology courses who consent to us using their data for research purposes. In an initial online questionnaire, participants will complete measures of meaning in life, optimism, positive affect, adaptive appraisals relevant to taking an exam, and expected grades. Approximately one to three weeks after completing this initial questionnaire, participants will take an exam in the course. Immediately after the exam, they will be asked to rate their current emotions (include distress) and adaptive appraisals relevant to the exam (e.g., "I was eager to tackle this exam while taking it. ", "I felt stressed while taking the exam").

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be undergraduate students in two psychology classes. Any adult who is over the age of 18 and who consents to us using their data for research purposes may participate. These studies will be completed as homework assignments.

q13.value: We will collect as much data as possible from two undergraduate courses (personality, social psychology). It is expected that we will have between 150-200 participants total who complete both parts of the surveys (across both classes).

q14.value: The total sample size will be based on the number of students who decide to take these survey measures.

question.value:
Meaning in Life Scale (Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006)
Optimism  (Scheier, Carver, & Bridges, 1994)
Mood: positive and negative affect items (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988)
Appraisals of challenging task (items adapted from Carver, Scheier, & Weintraub, 1989; Endler & Parker, 1994; Park 2010; Park 2016; Peacock & Wong, 1990)

Meaning in life, optimism, and positive affect scales will be formed with the mean of relevant items.

We are including several items to assess different cognitive appraisals pertaining to taking an exam. Based on our past research, we expect these items to form the following subscales: active coping, planning, positive reframing, worry/self-doubt/blame, and coping self-efficacy (time 1 measures); coping self-efficacy, worry/self-doubt and perceived exam performance (time 2 measures).  

Prior to calculating these subscales, we will examine alpha reliabilities of the items and also use factor analyses to examine whether the items form distinct factors. If multiple aspects of appraisals are found to load on one factor, then we will aggregate these scales in analyses unless there are compelling theoretical reasons to consider them distinct constructs.

Correlation and regression analyses will be used to examine the links between well-being variables, adaptive appraisals (at time 1 and time 2), and distress.

We will use hierarchical regression models and mediation models to examine if optimism accounts for the effect of meaning in life in predicting distress or adaptive appraisals. 

We will use structural equation modeling to examine the independent effects of meaning in life, optimism, and positive affect on coping appraisals and mood following the exam.

q20.value: In regression analyses, we will use standardized (z-scored) predictor variables.

q21.value: We will be assessing p-values below .05 using two-tailed tests.

q22.value: Duplicate responses from the same participant will be deleted.

q24.value:
We will examine how well-being variables and adaptive coping appraisals relate to students actual grades (for the class and exam) and expected grades.

To the extent that our sample size allows, we will examine if there are any important differences between the two class samples in well-being variables, coping appraisals (initial measures or post-team measures), and post-exam mood. 

We will examine if participants who completed both time 1 and time 2 measures had different levels of well-being than those who only completed time 1 measures. 

Exploratory analyses will probe effects of sex on study results.

q25.value: Our hypotheses were informed by our correlational and experimental research on this topic.

attributes.title: Individual variability in liking of social touch
attributes.description: This project will seek to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. We will also examine touch preferences in different UK cohorts, (for example among opposite and same-sex couples) and across different countries. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection focusing more generally on touch (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract relevant variables in order to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. Below we summarise our subprojects related to this global aim, which may appear as separate publications.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
All correlational analyses and linear models may be conducted using both Frequentist and Bayesian equivalent methods, and the strength of evidence for both the alternative and null hypothesis will be assessed. 

Depending on our regression results we may also decide to conduct secondary analysis using an in depth moderation analysis to more thoroughly explore the moderating effect of given variables.

For some analyses Generalised Additive Models (GAMs) may be used to assess differences in the outcome variable(s) as a function of the key factor(s) entered in the models. Trend analysis may also be used to visualise the data. Where we examine differences as a function of group status, group will be entered as a factor in the model.  Where multiple models are fitted for the same dependent variable, formal model selection will be conducted using Akaike Information Criteria extracted from the fitted models.

Given the unprecedented nature of Covid-19 there is also a high likelihood that additional analyses of interest will arise in the related sub-project within our research team or the wider community. 

In all scientific communications, any exploratory or additional analyses will be clearly labelled as such. Further, any deviations from these analyses will be noted. Where possible, we will pre-register future re-analyses of these data, for example as part of student projects or similar.

sample.value:
Our target sample size is a minimum of 252 for each sample that we plan to analyse in our regressions. We will collect a large opportunity sample with the aim of recruiting at least this number of participants for each sample of interest.

Our target sample size was calculated using G*Power software. Our goal was to obtain a sufficient sample size to run regression analyses with a maximum of 15 predictors, achieving .95 power to detect a medium effect size of f² = .15. Since we anticipate being able to recruit a large participant sample for the project, a more stringent alpha level of .01 was selected for the regression analysis. 

For group level ANOVA we require a minimum 105 per cell, based on a maximum of 2 groups and 14 covariates, achieving .95 power to detect a medium effect size of f = .25, with alpha error .05. 

For chi-square analyses we require a minimum sample of 145, based on a 2x2 contingency table, achieving .95 power to detect a medium effect size of w = .3, with alpha error .05. 

Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

analyses.value:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply alternative non-parametric tests, or bootstrapped corrected analyses (with at least 2000 iterations), drawing observations randomly with replacement. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 given sample size for all regressions, <.05 for group level comparisons. Significant effects in ANOVA will be followed by pairwise comparisons. In this case, Bonferroni corrections will be applied to reduce Type 1 error rate.


Subproject 1: What individual trait differences influence the likability of touch?

To identify traits associated with touch preference, the following variables will be correlated with Touchability Index:

Participant age
Emotional bond with the toucher
Most recent touch
Day/Week of completion
Attachment style (avoidance, anxiety)
Personality traits (agreeableness, openness to experience, neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness)

For significant correlations (defined as p <.005), data will be entered into regression analyses to test the relative contribution of a given predictor variable, while controlling for: age, gender of the participant, gender of the toucher, emotional bond, most recent touch, study completion date, and other significant correlates. Variables will be examined for multicollinearity, and adjustments made if necessary prior to conducting the regression analysis.

Regression analyses will be repeated for 1) partner touch, 2) friend touch, 3) stranger touch. Following these analyses, Fisher’s R to Z transformations will be carried out to examine whether relationships between individual difference factors and touch preference differ depending on toucher. A p <.05 criterion will be applied to test for significance in these comparisons. We will also compare beta weights were relevant between conditions using a p <.05 criterion.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. 


Subproject 2: How does body representation influence the liking of touch?

The following variables will be correlated with Touchability Index:

Body acceptance
Interoceptive awareness
Tactile sensitivity

For significant correlations (defined as p <.005), data will be entered into regression analyses to test the relative contribution of a given predictor variable, while controlling for relevant predictors identified in Subproject 1. Variables will be examined for multicollinearity, and adjustments made if necessary prior to conducting the regression analysis.

Regression analyses will be repeated for 1) partner touch, 2) friend touch, 3) stranger touch. Following these analyses, Fisher’s R to Z transformations will be carried out to examine whether relationships between individual difference factors and touch preference differ depending on toucher. A p <.05 criterion will be applied to test for significance in these comparisons. We will also compare beta weights were relevant between conditions using a p <.05 criterion.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. The analysis for partner touch will be carried out for heterosexual participants only.


Sub project 3: How does the likability of touch differ for same-sex and opposite-sex couples?

To examine this hypothesis, independent samples t-tests (or non-parametric alternative) will be used to compare TI for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Where groups differ in terms of relevant control variables (identified in Subproject 1), these will be included as covariates or additional main effects in these analyses (e.g. via ANCOVA). Follow-up comparisons will be conducted using paired comparisons with Bonferroni correction.

To examine the topography of touch preference in these couples, chi-square analysis will compare the frequency of ‘like’ and ‘dislike’ responses for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Analyses will be repeated for each body region (see Q3) to identify where preferences differ between groups.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment.


Subproject 4: What has been the impact of Covid-19 on likability of touch?

To examine this hypothesis, independent samples t-tests (or non-parametric alternative) will be used to compare TI in participant samples collected before and after key developments in Covid-19 (including but not limited to, the first ten confirmed cases; the first reported death; instigation of more restrictive social distancing measures) in a given country. Where samples differ in terms of relevant control variables (identified in Subproject 1), these will be included as covariates or additional main effects in these analyses (e.g. via ANCOVA). Follow-up comparisons will be conducted using t-tests and Bonferroni correction. This analysis will be repeated for partner, friend and stranger touch.

To examine the topography of touch preference in relation to Covid-19, chi-square analysis will compare the frequency of ‘like’ and ‘dislike’ responses for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Analyses will be repeated for each body region (see Q3), and for partner, friend, and stranger touch, to identify where preferences differ between groups.

These analyses will be carried out for participants who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. Analyses will be carried out in a UK samples, and where sample size is sufficient, in other countries affected by Covid-19 between 21/01/2020 and 30/02/2020.

outliers.value:
For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis. To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant. 

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.

dependent.value:
For each of 29 different regions of the body, participants are asked to indicate how they would feel if they were touched there, while in a public place. Participants can select from Like, Dislike, and Neutral. The task is carried out first while imagining that they are being touched by a person they are close to (participants can choose either a partner or friend they know well). Second, the task is repeated while imagining they are being touched by a stranger. All participants will complete both conditions. After each task, the participant rates their emotional bond to that person, on a scale from 1-10.

The dependent variable will be the stated preference: Like, Dislike or Neutral, for a given body part (e.g. forearm), and a given toucher (e.g. partner). A data-driven approach may also be taken to cluster different body parts into meaningful regions (e.g. intimate vs. non-intimate regions) based on the distribution of responses.

In addition, a continuous “Touchability Index” will be calculated for each participant and each toucher, by subtracting the number of ‘Dislike’ body parts from the number of ‘Like’ body parts. Possible scores will range from -29 to +29

conditions.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described below.

We are interested in the following predictor variables to assess how they influence body image:

1)	Personality (BFI-S; Hahn, Gottschling & Spinath, 2012). This consists of subscales for agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, openness to experience and neuroticism).
2)	Attachment style (ECR-12; Lafontaine et al., 2015. This consists of subscales for attachment avoidance and anxiety).
3)	Body acceptance (from Dresden Body Image Questionnaire, Scheffers et al., 2017)
4)	Interoceptive awareness (IAS; Murphy et al., 2020)
5)	Tactile sensitivity (from the Glasgow Sensory Questionnaire, Robertson & Simmons, 2013)
6)	Toucher (Partner/Friend/Stranger)
7)	Sexual orientation: Participants will be grouped according to their own and their partner’s gender into same-sex couples (Male-Male or Female-Female) and opposite-sex couples (Male-Female or Female-Male).
8)	Country of residence
9)	(If UK) Region of the UK

We will also control for:

1)	Age
2)	Gender of the participant
3)	Gender of the toucher
4)	Emotional bond with the toucher (1-10 rating scale, 10 = maximum possible bond)
5)	When was the last time that somebody touched you intentionally (six-point scale from ‘In the last hour’ to ‘Over a year ago’
6)	Day of completion or week of completion depending on number of survey respondents (to be defined after data is accessed). 

Analyses in this project will be carried out for individuals who do not report a disability, long-term condition or impairment. However, we plan to examine particular groups of interest in future subprojects, including participants with autism spectrum conditions, participants who are visually impaired, and participants with mobility impairments.

hypothesis.value:
This project will seek to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. We will also examine touch preferences in different UK cohorts, (for example among opposite and same-sex couples) and across different countries. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection focusing more generally on touch (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract relevant variables in order to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. Below we summarise our subprojects related to this global aim, which may appear as separate publications.


Subproject 1: What individual trait differences influence the likability of touch?

Previous research has demonstrated that personality traits agreeableness and openness to experience are associated with differences in touch attitudes/experiences (e.g. Dorros et al. 2008). Agreeableness is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch in from a partner, across all areas of the body. Openness to experience is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch from a partner, specifically in non-intimate areas. We will extend previous work by also examining liking of touch from a stranger. Due to the novelty of this question, we do not make specific predictions for the stranger condition.

Anxious attachment in relationships has previously been linked to increased effectiveness of touch in reducing pain; while avoidant attachment is associated with reduced effectiveness (Krahé et al., 2018). Greater attachment anxiety is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch, specifically to intimate areas of the body, in the partner or close friend condition. Greater attachment avoidance is predicted to be associated with reduced liking of touch in all conditions.


Subproject 2: How does body representation/perception influence the liking of touch?

Based on previous work identifying an association between body image and comfort with physical touch (Orbach & Mikulincer, 1998), greater body acceptance is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch in all conditions

Prior work has shown that interoceptive awareness is associated with differences in the perceived pleasantness of touch (Crucianelli et al., 2018) and others have argued it is integral to emotional experience (e.g. Craig, 2003). Based on these suggestions, we predict that greater interoceptive awareness will be associated with greater liking of touch, across all conditions.

Tactile sensitivity refers to responsiveness to tactile stimulation. Tactile hypersensitivity could be expected to either make touch experiences more pleasant, or more unpleasant. We therefore predict to see differences in touch preference related to tactile sensitivity, but do not make a directional hypothesis.


Subproject 3: How does the likability of touch differ for same-sex and opposite-sex couples?

Prior work has reported that same-sex couples are less likely to display affection publicly (Kent & El-Alayli, 2011). We therefore predict to see differences between heterosexual and same-sex couples in the liking of touch from a partner (in a public place). We predict that these differences will be focused on parts of the body typically engaged in intimate touch.


Subproject 4: What has been the impact of Covid-19 on likability of touch?

The data for this project has been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which is likely to have changed participants’ comfort with social touch. We will control for this factor in all other subprojects by including a measure linked to the date of survey completion as an additional predictor variable. In addition, we propose to examine how touch preferences vary as a function of time point by comparing responses that may coincide with key developments in Covid-19 (including but not limited to, the first ten confirmed cases; the first reported death; instigation of more restrictive social distancing measures). For example, in England, before 24/02/20 (Time 1) versus after 24/02/20 (Time 2) based on first ten cases reported by Public Health England. Here, we predict that the likability of touch from a stranger will be reduced from Time 1 to Time 2. We also expect to see differences in preference for partner touch from Time 1 to Time 2, however the effects are less clear in this case, and so we do not make directional hypotheses related to partner touch.

Additional considerations:

Previous research has shown an association between emotional bond and the perceived acceptability of touch (Suvilehto et al., 2019). Based on this finding, a stronger emotional bond with the toucher is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch. Emotional bond will be included as a control factor in all subprojects.

The hypotheses above are made for a UK sample. However, prior research has identified geographical differences in social touch behaviour. We predict that touch preferences will also differ between groups of participants based in different countries. Our survey is available worldwide, and based on prior surveys of this type that have been conducted by the BBC and Wellcome Collection, we envisage suitable sample sizes are likely in additional European and North American countries. However, as an opportunity sampling method is being used, we will not know the location of all participants until the study closes. As such, while we expect to see variation in the factors predicting touch attitudes across different countries, we refrain from making specific directional hypotheses at this time.

Additional groups of interest in relation to individual differences in touch attitudes include participants with autism spectrum conditions, and visual or mobility impairments. Any analyses in these groups will likely form separate papers, depending upon the sample of size of participants recruited who report these conditions. Further details on these analyses will be registered as additional sub-projects once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed.

study_type_other.value: Additional Information related to Q1: The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). For a full list of measures included in the survey, please see the attached document in the following linked registration: https://osf.io/2xgny. For this project we will extract data specific to the likability of touch and additional related factors that may contribute to this. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes (closure date is 30.03.20; earliest full data access will be 31.03.20).

Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.
registration_responses.analyses:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply alternative non-parametric tests, or bootstrapped corrected analyses (with at least 2000 iterations), drawing observations randomly with replacement. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 given sample size for all regressions, <.05 for group level comparisons. Significant effects in ANOVA will be followed by pairwise comparisons. In this case, Bonferroni corrections will be applied to reduce Type 1 error rate.


Subproject 1: What individual trait differences influence the likability of touch?

To identify traits associated with touch preference, the following variables will be correlated with Touchability Index:

Participant age
Emotional bond with the toucher
Most recent touch
Day/Week of completion
Attachment style (avoidance, anxiety)
Personality traits (agreeableness, openness to experience, neuroticism, extraversion, conscientiousness)

For significant correlations (defined as p <.005), data will be entered into regression analyses to test the relative contribution of a given predictor variable, while controlling for: age, gender of the participant, gender of the toucher, emotional bond, most recent touch, study completion date, and other significant correlates. Variables will be examined for multicollinearity, and adjustments made if necessary prior to conducting the regression analysis.

Regression analyses will be repeated for 1) partner touch, 2) friend touch, 3) stranger touch. Following these analyses, Fisher’s R to Z transformations will be carried out to examine whether relationships between individual difference factors and touch preference differ depending on toucher. A p <.05 criterion will be applied to test for significance in these comparisons. We will also compare beta weights were relevant between conditions using a p <.05 criterion.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. 


Subproject 2: How does body representation influence the liking of touch?

The following variables will be correlated with Touchability Index:

Body acceptance
Interoceptive awareness
Tactile sensitivity

For significant correlations (defined as p <.005), data will be entered into regression analyses to test the relative contribution of a given predictor variable, while controlling for relevant predictors identified in Subproject 1. Variables will be examined for multicollinearity, and adjustments made if necessary prior to conducting the regression analysis.

Regression analyses will be repeated for 1) partner touch, 2) friend touch, 3) stranger touch. Following these analyses, Fisher’s R to Z transformations will be carried out to examine whether relationships between individual difference factors and touch preference differ depending on toucher. A p <.05 criterion will be applied to test for significance in these comparisons. We will also compare beta weights were relevant between conditions using a p <.05 criterion.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. The analysis for partner touch will be carried out for heterosexual participants only.


Sub project 3: How does the likability of touch differ for same-sex and opposite-sex couples?

To examine this hypothesis, independent samples t-tests (or non-parametric alternative) will be used to compare TI for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Where groups differ in terms of relevant control variables (identified in Subproject 1), these will be included as covariates or additional main effects in these analyses (e.g. via ANCOVA). Follow-up comparisons will be conducted using paired comparisons with Bonferroni correction.

To examine the topography of touch preference in these couples, chi-square analysis will compare the frequency of ‘like’ and ‘dislike’ responses for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Analyses will be repeated for each body region (see Q3) to identify where preferences differ between groups.

These analyses will be carried out on a UK sample who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment.


Subproject 4: What has been the impact of Covid-19 on likability of touch?

To examine this hypothesis, independent samples t-tests (or non-parametric alternative) will be used to compare TI in participant samples collected before and after key developments in Covid-19 (including but not limited to, the first ten confirmed cases; the first reported death; instigation of more restrictive social distancing measures) in a given country. Where samples differ in terms of relevant control variables (identified in Subproject 1), these will be included as covariates or additional main effects in these analyses (e.g. via ANCOVA). Follow-up comparisons will be conducted using t-tests and Bonferroni correction. This analysis will be repeated for partner, friend and stranger touch.

To examine the topography of touch preference in relation to Covid-19, chi-square analysis will compare the frequency of ‘like’ and ‘dislike’ responses for partner touch in same-sex and opposite-sex couples. Analyses will be repeated for each body region (see Q3), and for partner, friend, and stranger touch, to identify where preferences differ between groups.

These analyses will be carried out for participants who do not report any disability, long-term condition or impairment. Analyses will be carried out in a UK samples, and where sample size is sufficient, in other countries affected by Covid-19 between 21/01/2020 and 30/02/2020.
registration_responses.outliers:
For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis. To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant. 

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.
registration_responses.dependent:
For each of 29 different regions of the body, participants are asked to indicate how they would feel if they were touched there, while in a public place. Participants can select from Like, Dislike, and Neutral. The task is carried out first while imagining that they are being touched by a person they are close to (participants can choose either a partner or friend they know well). Second, the task is repeated while imagining they are being touched by a stranger. All participants will complete both conditions. After each task, the participant rates their emotional bond to that person, on a scale from 1-10.

The dependent variable will be the stated preference: Like, Dislike or Neutral, for a given body part (e.g. forearm), and a given toucher (e.g. partner). A data-driven approach may also be taken to cluster different body parts into meaningful regions (e.g. intimate vs. non-intimate regions) based on the distribution of responses.

In addition, a continuous “Touchability Index” will be calculated for each participant and each toucher, by subtracting the number of ‘Dislike’ body parts from the number of ‘Like’ body parts. Possible scores will range from -29 to +29
registration_responses.conditions:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described below.

We are interested in the following predictor variables to assess how they influence body image:

1)	Personality (BFI-S; Hahn, Gottschling & Spinath, 2012). This consists of subscales for agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, openness to experience and neuroticism).
2)	Attachment style (ECR-12; Lafontaine et al., 2015. This consists of subscales for attachment avoidance and anxiety).
3)	Body acceptance (from Dresden Body Image Questionnaire, Scheffers et al., 2017)
4)	Interoceptive awareness (IAS; Murphy et al., 2020)
5)	Tactile sensitivity (from the Glasgow Sensory Questionnaire, Robertson & Simmons, 2013)
6)	Toucher (Partner/Friend/Stranger)
7)	Sexual orientation: Participants will be grouped according to their own and their partner’s gender into same-sex couples (Male-Male or Female-Female) and opposite-sex couples (Male-Female or Female-Male).
8)	Country of residence
9)	(If UK) Region of the UK

We will also control for:

1)	Age
2)	Gender of the participant
3)	Gender of the toucher
4)	Emotional bond with the toucher (1-10 rating scale, 10 = maximum possible bond)
5)	When was the last time that somebody touched you intentionally (six-point scale from ‘In the last hour’ to ‘Over a year ago’
6)	Day of completion or week of completion depending on number of survey respondents (to be defined after data is accessed). 

Analyses in this project will be carried out for individuals who do not report a disability, long-term condition or impairment. However, we plan to examine particular groups of interest in future subprojects, including participants with autism spectrum conditions, participants who are visually impaired, and participants with mobility impairments.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This project will seek to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. We will also examine touch preferences in different UK cohorts, (for example among opposite and same-sex couples) and across different countries. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection focusing more generally on touch (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract relevant variables in order to explore individual differences in preferences for touch on different parts of the body. Below we summarise our subprojects related to this global aim, which may appear as separate publications.


Subproject 1: What individual trait differences influence the likability of touch?

Previous research has demonstrated that personality traits agreeableness and openness to experience are associated with differences in touch attitudes/experiences (e.g. Dorros et al. 2008). Agreeableness is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch in from a partner, across all areas of the body. Openness to experience is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch from a partner, specifically in non-intimate areas. We will extend previous work by also examining liking of touch from a stranger. Due to the novelty of this question, we do not make specific predictions for the stranger condition.

Anxious attachment in relationships has previously been linked to increased effectiveness of touch in reducing pain; while avoidant attachment is associated with reduced effectiveness (Krahé et al., 2018). Greater attachment anxiety is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch, specifically to intimate areas of the body, in the partner or close friend condition. Greater attachment avoidance is predicted to be associated with reduced liking of touch in all conditions.


Subproject 2: How does body representation/perception influence the liking of touch?

Based on previous work identifying an association between body image and comfort with physical touch (Orbach & Mikulincer, 1998), greater body acceptance is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch in all conditions

Prior work has shown that interoceptive awareness is associated with differences in the perceived pleasantness of touch (Crucianelli et al., 2018) and others have argued it is integral to emotional experience (e.g. Craig, 2003). Based on these suggestions, we predict that greater interoceptive awareness will be associated with greater liking of touch, across all conditions.

Tactile sensitivity refers to responsiveness to tactile stimulation. Tactile hypersensitivity could be expected to either make touch experiences more pleasant, or more unpleasant. We therefore predict to see differences in touch preference related to tactile sensitivity, but do not make a directional hypothesis.


Subproject 3: How does the likability of touch differ for same-sex and opposite-sex couples?

Prior work has reported that same-sex couples are less likely to display affection publicly (Kent & El-Alayli, 2011). We therefore predict to see differences between heterosexual and same-sex couples in the liking of touch from a partner (in a public place). We predict that these differences will be focused on parts of the body typically engaged in intimate touch.


Subproject 4: What has been the impact of Covid-19 on likability of touch?

The data for this project has been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which is likely to have changed participants’ comfort with social touch. We will control for this factor in all other subprojects by including a measure linked to the date of survey completion as an additional predictor variable. In addition, we propose to examine how touch preferences vary as a function of time point by comparing responses that may coincide with key developments in Covid-19 (including but not limited to, the first ten confirmed cases; the first reported death; instigation of more restrictive social distancing measures). For example, in England, before 24/02/20 (Time 1) versus after 24/02/20 (Time 2) based on first ten cases reported by Public Health England. Here, we predict that the likability of touch from a stranger will be reduced from Time 1 to Time 2. We also expect to see differences in preference for partner touch from Time 1 to Time 2, however the effects are less clear in this case, and so we do not make directional hypotheses related to partner touch.

Additional considerations:

Previous research has shown an association between emotional bond and the perceived acceptability of touch (Suvilehto et al., 2019). Based on this finding, a stronger emotional bond with the toucher is predicted to be associated with greater liking of touch. Emotional bond will be included as a control factor in all subprojects.

The hypotheses above are made for a UK sample. However, prior research has identified geographical differences in social touch behaviour. We predict that touch preferences will also differ between groups of participants based in different countries. Our survey is available worldwide, and based on prior surveys of this type that have been conducted by the BBC and Wellcome Collection, we envisage suitable sample sizes are likely in additional European and North American countries. However, as an opportunity sampling method is being used, we will not know the location of all participants until the study closes. As such, while we expect to see variation in the factors predicting touch attitudes across different countries, we refrain from making specific directional hypotheses at this time.

Additional groups of interest in relation to individual differences in touch attitudes include participants with autism spectrum conditions, and visual or mobility impairments. Any analyses in these groups will likely form separate papers, depending upon the sample of size of participants recruited who report these conditions. Further details on these analyses will be registered as additional sub-projects once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed.
registration_responses.study_type_other: Additional Information related to Q1: The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). For a full list of measures included in the survey, please see the attached document in the following linked registration: https://osf.io/2xgny. For this project we will extract data specific to the likability of touch and additional related factors that may contribute to this. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes (closure date is 30.03.20; earliest full data access will be 31.03.20).

attributes.title: Social and non-social wellbeing during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic
attributes.description: Covid-19 emerged at the end of 2019 in Wuhan, China - and spread globally in the first few months of 2020 - leading to 'lockdown' in different areas around the world. This situation has led to seismic changes in day-to-day life, with people having been told to 'socially distance', 'socially isolate', work from home and stay indoors.  During this period we were collecting cross-sectional data on social (loneliness) and non-social wellbeing (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) - start date of data collection 21/01/20, end date of data collection 30/03/20. Given our large sample size, we plan to access study responses linked to social and non-social wellbeing and examine responses at different time points in order to examine changes in social and non-social wellbeing over this unusual period of time.  We propose a number of projects that will investigate how any changes in social and non-social wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic are associated with the following: 1) touch attitudes, 2) attachment, 3) age, and 4) gender. We propose to address these questions in a typical UK adult sample (where we expect the majority of our opportunity sample to reside). Depending on sample characteristics (to be confirmed after final data is accessed - expected on 31/03/20) we will also seek to examine social and non-social wellbeing during the coronavirus pandemic in the following groups should we reach minimum power requirements: UK adults from countries outside of the UK; Autism Spectrum Disorder; Mobile Impaired; Visually Impaired.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Social and non-social wellbeing during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic

other.value:
All correlational analyses and linear models will be conducted using both Frequentist and Bayesian equivalent methods, and the strength of evidence for both the alternative and null hypothesis will be assessed. 

Our survey is worldwide, but given the likely main UK base of participants we plan to  restrict our analyses to the UK. Specifically, UK adults who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments. Depending on sample characteristics (to be confirmed after final data is accessed - expected on 31/03/20) we may examine regional differences within the UK.

We may also seek to examine social and non-social wellbeing during the coronavirus pandemic in the following groups should we reach minimum power requirements: UK adults from countries outside of the UK; Autism Spectrum Disorder; Mobile Impaired; Visually Impaired; specific professional groups. Any such analysis will be registered as a further subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained. 

Depending on our regression results we may also decide to conduct  secondary analysis using an in depth moderation analysis to more thoroughly explore the moderating effect of given variables on the relationships between wellbeing and coronavirus.

For some analyses Generalised Additive Models (GAMs) may be used to assess differences in the outcome variable(s) as a function of the key factor(s) entered in the models. Trend analysis may also be used to visualise the data. Where we examine differences as a function of group status, group will be entered as a factor in the model.  Where multiple models are fitted for the same dependent variable, formal model selection will be conducted using Akaike Information Criteria extracted from the fitted models.

Given the unprecedented nature of Covid-19 there is also a high likelihood that additional analyses of interest will arise within our research team or the wider community. In all scientific communications, any exploratory or additional analyses will be clearly labelled as such. Further, any deviations from analyses highlighted above will be noted. Where possible, we will pre-register future re-analyses of these data, for example as part of student projects or similar.

sample.value:
G*Power  statistical software will be used to conduct a power analysis. Our goal is to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. This test will be performed in order to check the minimum sample size required for statistical power for  any test conducted. The minimum sample size required per test will be used for stratification purposes to identify relevant groups where we do or do not have sufficient statistical power (e.g. the minimum sample required per country should we be able to conduct country specific analyses outside of the UK). 

Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

analyses.value:
Sub-Project 1: How have loneliness and wellbeing changed over time as the coronavirus pandemic has spread? 

We will conduct separate regression analyses to explore whether time of testing (defined as week or day of survey completion) predict changes in social (UCLA Loneliness Scale) and non-social wellbeing (Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale). We will control for: age and gender. 

For group comparisons by age (binned in at least ten year increments) and gender, we will also compare social and non-social wellbeing scores using  t-tests, ANOVA or a non-parametric alternative. For these analyses, Testing Time will used as an independent variable. Testing Time will be defined by events that coincide with key developments in Covid-19 (including but not limited to, the first ten confirmed cases; the first reported death; instigation of more restrictive social distancing measures) in a given region of interest (e.g. in England ten cases would be before 24/02/20 versus after 24/02/20 based on cases reported by Public Health England). Any significant effects will be followed up using Bonferroni correction. If groupings differ on demographic variables (e.g. region of UK), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses.

Sub-Project 2: How do differences in attitudes towards social touch interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic?

We will conduct separate regression analyses to explore whether the interaction between time of testing (defined as week or day of survey completion) and attitudes towards touch predict changes in social (UCLA Loneliness Scale) and non-social wellbeing (Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale). We will control for: age, attachment, and gender. 

We also intend to use k-means cluster analysis to group participants based on scores related to attitudes towards touch. We will also compare social and non-social wellbeing scores across these groups using  ANOVA or a non-parametric alternative. For these analyses, Testing Time (as defined in the group analysis above) will also be used as an independent variable. Any significant effects will be followed up using Bonferroni correction. If groupings differ on demographic variables (e.g. region of UK), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses

Sub-Project 3: How do differences in attachment style interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic?

We will conduct separate regression analyses to explore whether the interaction between time of testing (defined as week or day of survey completion) and attachment scores predict changes in social (UCLA Loneliness Scale) and non-social wellbeing (Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale). We will control for: age and gender. 

We also intend to use k-means cluster analysis to group participants based on scores related to attachment. We will also compare social and non-social wellbeing scores across these groups using  ANOVA or a non-parametric alternative. For these analyses, Testing Time (as defined in the group analysis above) will also be used as an independent variable. Any significant effects will be followed up using Bonferroni correction. If groupings differ on demographic variables (e.g. region of UK), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses

General analysis assumptions:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 for all regressions, <.05 for all group level comparisons (e.g. ANOVA).

To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis.

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.

dependent.value: Our main dependent variables of interest are mental and social wellbeing, which will be measured via scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Stewart-Brown, 2009) and UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, 1996) respectively.

conditions.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described above/below.

Participants to be included in the analysis will be asked to complete all of the measures. Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate. Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. 

We will assess the following variables to assess how they influence wellbeing in the context of the coronavirus pandemic (2020):
1 Attitudes towards and experience of touch: The Social Touch questionnaire (Wilhelm et al., 2001) produces a single total score and measuring attitudes towards social touch. Responses from a Portuguese sample have previously identified three underlying subscales, representing Dislike of Physical Touch, Liking of Familiar Physical Touch, and Liking of Public Physical Touch (Vieira et al, 2016).

2.	Age

3.	Gender

4.	Attachment style: Experiences in Close Relationship Scale-Short Form (Wei, 2007); Measures two subscales: Anxiety and Avoidance. 

5. Date of testing: The date of testing will be extracted to enable us to link data to changes in coronavirus pandemic.

Note, we will also extract broader demographic details from the Touch Test for sample comparisons and descriptions (for a copy of full survey see Study Design - https://osf.io/2xgny).

hypothesis.value:
Covid-19 emerged at the end of 2019 in Wuhan, China - and spread globally in the first few months of 2020 - leading to 'lockdown' in different areas around the world. This situation has led to seismic changes in day-to-day life, with people having been told to 'socially distance', 'socially isolate', work from home and stay indoors.  During this period we were collecting cross-sectional data on social (loneliness) and non-social wellbeing (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) - start date of data collection 21/01/20, end date of data collection 30/03/20. Given our large sample size, we plan to access study responses linked to social and non-social wellbeing and examine responses at different time points in order to examine changes in social and non-social wellbeing over this unusual period of time.  We propose a number of projects that will investigate the following questions (which will be treated as separate sub-projects as indicated; note, we intend that sub-projects will be published separately): 

1) Sub-Project 1: How have loneliness and wellbeing changed over time as the coronavirus pandemic has spread? We expect increases in loneliness and decreases in wellbeing to have been observed. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender.

2) Sub-Project 2: How do differences in attitudes towards social touch interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic? We predict that participants who have high social touch attitudes will show differences in their loneliness and wellbeing changes associated with the coronavirus pandemic compared with participants who have low social touch attitudes. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender in this context.

3) Sub-Project 3: How do differences in attachment style interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic? Given that attachment style has been linked with differences in wellbeing and that social isolation/distancing may influence these attachment styles differently, we predict that participants who score high in anxious attachment will show differences in their loneliness and wellbeing changes associated with the coronavirus pandemic compared with participants who score low in anxious attachment. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender in this context.

study_type_other.value: Additional Information related to Data Collection: Since 21/01/20 we have been collecting cross-sectional data via an observational survey on social (loneliness) and non-social wellbeing (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) - start date of data collection 21/01/20, end date of data collection 30/03/20. There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to social and non-social wellbeing in order to assess how these factors have changed during the coronavirus pandemic. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes (closure date is 30.03.20; earliest full data access will be 31.03.20).

We will also compare social and non-social wellbeing scores across these groups using  ANOVA or a non-parametric alternative. For these analyses, Testing Time (as defined in the group analysis above) will also be used as an independent variable. Any significant effects will be followed up using Bonferroni correction. If groupings differ on demographic variables (e.g. region of UK), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses

Sub-Project 3: How do differences in attachment style interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic?

We will conduct separate regression analyses to explore whether the interaction between time of testing (defined as week or day of survey completion) and attachment scores predict changes in social (UCLA Loneliness Scale) and non-social wellbeing (Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale). We will control for: age and gender. 

We also intend to use k-means cluster analysis to group participants based on scores related to attachment. We will also compare social and non-social wellbeing scores across these groups using  ANOVA or a non-parametric alternative. For these analyses, Testing Time (as defined in the group analysis above) will also be used as an independent variable. Any significant effects will be followed up using Bonferroni correction. If groupings differ on demographic variables (e.g. region of UK), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses

General analysis assumptions:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 for all regressions, <.05 for all group level comparisons (e.g. ANOVA).
registration_responses.outliers:
To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis.

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.
registration_responses.dependent: Our main dependent variables of interest are mental and social wellbeing, which will be measured via scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Stewart-Brown, 2009) and UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, 1996) respectively.
registration_responses.conditions:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described above/below.

Participants to be included in the analysis will be asked to complete all of the measures. Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate. Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. 

We will assess the following variables to assess how they influence wellbeing in the context of the coronavirus pandemic (2020):
1 Attitudes towards and experience of touch: The Social Touch questionnaire (Wilhelm et al., 2001) produces a single total score and measuring attitudes towards social touch. Responses from a Portuguese sample have previously identified three underlying subscales, representing Dislike of Physical Touch, Liking of Familiar Physical Touch, and Liking of Public Physical Touch (Vieira et al, 2016).

2.	Age

3.	Gender

4.	Attachment style: Experiences in Close Relationship Scale-Short Form (Wei, 2007); Measures two subscales: Anxiety and Avoidance. 

5. Date of testing: The date of testing will be extracted to enable us to link data to changes in coronavirus pandemic.

Note, we will also extract broader demographic details from the Touch Test for sample comparisons and descriptions (for a copy of full survey see Study Design - https://osf.io/2xgny).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Covid-19 emerged at the end of 2019 in Wuhan, China - and spread globally in the first few months of 2020 - leading to 'lockdown' in different areas around the world. This situation has led to seismic changes in day-to-day life, with people having been told to 'socially distance', 'socially isolate', work from home and stay indoors.  During this period we were collecting cross-sectional data on social (loneliness) and non-social wellbeing (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) - start date of data collection 21/01/20, end date of data collection 30/03/20. Given our large sample size, we plan to access study responses linked to social and non-social wellbeing and examine responses at different time points in order to examine changes in social and non-social wellbeing over this unusual period of time.  We propose a number of projects that will investigate the following questions (which will be treated as separate sub-projects as indicated; note, we intend that sub-projects will be published separately): 

1) Sub-Project 1: How have loneliness and wellbeing changed over time as the coronavirus pandemic has spread? We expect increases in loneliness and decreases in wellbeing to have been observed. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender.

2) Sub-Project 2: How do differences in attitudes towards social touch interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic? We predict that participants who have high social touch attitudes will show differences in their loneliness and wellbeing changes associated with the coronavirus pandemic compared with participants who have low social touch attitudes. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender in this context.

3) Sub-Project 3: How do differences in attachment style interact with differences in loneliness and wellbeing associated with the coronavirus pandemic? Given that attachment style has been linked with differences in wellbeing and that social isolation/distancing may influence these attachment styles differently, we predict that participants who score high in anxious attachment will show differences in their loneliness and wellbeing changes associated with the coronavirus pandemic compared with participants who score low in anxious attachment. We will also explore differences in loneliness and wellbeing according to age and gender in this context.
registration_responses.study_type_other: Additional Information related to Data Collection: Since 21/01/20 we have been collecting cross-sectional data via an observational survey on social (loneliness) and non-social wellbeing (in the context of a wider study focusing more generally on touch) - start date of data collection 21/01/20, end date of data collection 30/03/20. There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to social and non-social wellbeing in order to assess how these factors have changed during the coronavirus pandemic. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes (closure date is 30.03.20; earliest full data access will be 31.03.20).

attributes.title: Search and Search Result Citation Files
attributes.description: This dataset is part of a study that used scoping review methodology to collect and verify the applicability of the phrase "Food Studies" in bibliographic records across five databases. Five large bibliographic databases were identified for size, relevance to food studies, and subject metadata standards. These were ProQuest Central (PQC), EBSCO Discovery Service (EDS), Web Of Science (WOS), PubMed (PM), and PubAg. The phrase “food studies” was then searched within each database, using a scholarly or peer-reviewed filter. The date range for the articles was all-time, through the date of the final search (December 3, 2019.)
