attributes.title: Actual and Perceived Posttraumatic Growth Following the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Pandemic: A Prospective Longitudinal Study
attributes.description: The primary purpose of this study is to examine trajectories of actual and perceived posttraumatic growth (PTG; i.e., positive personality change) following the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic disaster in the U.S. The secondary purpose of this study is to examine predictors of psychological resilience after a pandemic disaster. Two months predisaster (December 2019), a sample of U.S. adults with a chronic health condition (N = 453) completed measures of positive traits (hope, grit, optimism, and resilience), religiousness/spirituality (religious commitment, fortitude, and coping), mental health (depression, anxiety, and psychological flourishing), personal suffering, and lifetime trauma exposure. At 2 months and 4 months postdisaster (April and June 2020), participants will complete these measures again, as well as measures of resource loss, perceived stress, social support, and perceived posttraumatic growth.

q1.value: Edward Britt Davis, Daryl R. Van Tongeren, Don E. Davis, Joshua Hook, Jamie Dean Aten, Kent Annan, Everett Worthington

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1 (directional): Perceived PTG (retrospective self-report on the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory–Short Form [PTGI-SF]) will be weakly positively related to actual (prospective) increases in (1a) positive traits and (1b) religiousness/spirituality.

Hypothesis 2 (directional): Actual improvement in mental health will be weakly to moderately positively related to actual (prospective) increases in (2a) positive traits and (2b) religiousness/spirituality.

Hypothesis 3 (directional): Perceived PTG will be (3a) weakly positively related to concurrently measured mental health but will be (3b) unrelated to prospectively measured change in mental health.

Hypothesis 4 (directional): Actual increases in positive traits will be weakly to moderately positively related to actual increases in religiousness/spirituality.

Hypothesis 5 (directional): The average trajectory of perceived PTG will indicate an increase in perceived PTG (5a), whereas there will be an average trajectory of decline in participants’ actual (prospectively measured) change in positive traits (5b), religiousness/spirituality (5c), and mental health (5d).

Hypothesis 6 (directional): The following will be significant predictors of postdisaster psychological resilience (e.g., minimal depression and anxiety symptoms [scores of 4 or lower on the Patient Health Questionnaire–9 (PHQ-9) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder–7 (GAD-7)]): (6a) older age, (6b) male sex/gender, (6c) lower socioeconomic status, (6d) lower predisaster trauma exposure, (6e) lower predisaster personal suffering, (6f) higher predisaster positive traits, (6g) higher predisaster religiousness/spirituality, (6h) higher predisaster mental health, (6i) lower disaster-related resource loss, (6j) lower postdisaster perceived stress, and (6k) higher postdisaster social support.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This observational longitudinal study involves a cohort design (U.S. adults with at least one chronic health condition) with repeated measures across three waves: (a) December 2019 (2-months predisaster), (b) April 2020 (2-months postdisaster), and (c) June 2020 (4-months postdisaster).

However, this study’s data was actually collected across five waves: (a) August 2019 (6-months predisaster; N = 1090), (b) December 2019 (2-months predisaster; N = 453), (c) February 2020 (peridisaster; N = 302), (d) April 2020 (2-months postdisaster), and (e) June 2020 (4-months postdisaster). 

In the current study, we will not be using the data from August 2019 or February 2020, because those data are being used for another study that is solely focusing on the data from August 2019, December 2019, and February 2020.

Furthermore, the data from February 2020 might obfuscate the results of the current study, because different parts of the U.S. were experiencing varying levels of physical and media exposure to the coronavirus (COVID-19) during that month.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: As of the date of submission (March 30, 2020), the data from August 2019, December 2019, and February 2020 exist and we have accessed it, but no analysis has been conducted related to the current study’s research plan or hypotheses.

question.value: A large sample (N = 1090) of U.S. adults with at least one chronic health condition were recruited by Qualtrics Panel in August 2019 (three inclusion rules: age 18 or older, current resident of the U.S., have at least one chronic health condition). This sample was recruited using participant quotas that would optimize the representativeness of the sample, relative to the U.S. adult general population. Specifically, quotas were set up to optimize representativeness in terms of age, sex/gender, U.S. region (Midwest, Northeast, South, West), race/ethnicity, and religious affiliation. At each of the data-collection waves, participants completed the 15-minute survey online via Qualtrics and were then compensated $5 for their participation (which was paid to them via their panel provider).

q11.value: We had 453 people complete the study measures in December 2019 (2-months predisaster). We will attempt to recruit as many of these same individuals as possible to complete the study measures in April 2020 (Wave 2: 2-months postdisaster) and June 2020 (Wave 3: 4-months postdisaster). Given expected attrition of 25% per wave, we anticipate approximately 340 people will participate in Wave 2 and 255 people will participate in Wave 3.

question.value:
1. Trait hope, as measured by the Adult Hope Scale (AHS; Snyder et al., 1991)
2. Persevering hope (i.e., the motivation to persist toward a desired goal even when it seems unlikely or impossible), as measured by the Holding Onto Positive Expectations (HOPE) Scale (Rueger et al., 2020) 
3. Trait grit, as measured by the Short Grit Scale (Grit-S; Duckworth & Quinn, 2009)
4. Trait optimism, as measured by the Life Orientation Test–Revised (LOT-R; Scheier et al., 1994)
5. Trait resilience, as measured by the Brief Resilience Scale (BRS; Smith et al., 2008)
6. Religious commitment, as measured by the Religious Commitment Inventory–10 (RCI-10; Worthington et al., 2003)
7. Spiritual fortitude, as measured by the Spiritual Fortitude Scale–9 (SFS-9; Van Tongeren et al., 2019)
8. Positive and negative religious coping, as measured by the Brief RCOPE (Pargament et al., 2011)
9. Depression symptoms, as measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire–9 (PHQ-9; Kroenke et al., 2001)
10. Anxiety symptoms, as measured by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder–7 (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006)
11. Psychological flourishing, as measured by the Flourishing Scale (Diener et al., 2010)
12. Personal suffering, as measured by the Personal Suffering Assessment (VanderWeele, 2019)
13. Lifetime exposure to traumatic events, as measured by the Traumatic Life Events Questionnaire (Kubany et al., 2000)
14. Disaster-related resource loss (loss of interpersonal resources, psychological resources, physical health resources, and economic resources), as measured by 12 items (3 items each) from the Conservation of Resources–Evaluation (COR-E; Hobfoll et al., 1995)
15. Perceived stress, as measured by the Perceived Stress Scale–10 (PSS-10; Cohen & Williamson, 1988)
16. Emotional and instrumental social support, as measured by the Medical Outcomes Study–Social Support Survey–Short Form (MOS-SSS-SF; Moser et al., 2014)
17. Perceived posttraumatic growth, as measured by the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory–Short Form (Cann et al., 2010)
18. Sociodemographic variables: age, sex/gender, sexual orientation, race/ethnicity, U.S. region (Midwest, Northeast, South, West), marital status, education level, household income, household size, religious importance, religious affiliation, and self-rated physical health
19. COVID-19 variables: COVID-19 exposure (whether participant or someone they know has been diagnosed with, quarantined because of, or died from COVID-19) and COVID-19 fears (as measured by 4 modified items from the Ebola Fear Inventory [Blakey et al., 2015])

Hypothesis 1 (directional): Perceived PTG (retrospective self-report on the Post-Traumatic Growth Inventory–Short Form [PTGI-SF]) will be weakly positively related to actual (prospective) increases in (1a) positive traits and (1b) religiousness/spirituality.
1. We will test this hypothesis using correlational or regression analyses.

Hypothesis 2 (directional): Actual improvement in mental health will be weakly to moderately positively related to actual (prospective) increases in (2a) positive traits and (2b) religiousness/spirituality.
2. We will test this hypothesis using correlational or regression analyses.

Hypothesis 3 (directional): Perceived PTG will be (3a) weakly positively related to concurrently measured mental health but will be (3b) unrelated to prospectively measured change in mental health.
3. We will test this hypothesis using correlational or regression analyses.

Hypothesis 4 (directional): Actual increases in positive traits will be weakly to moderately positively related to actual increases in religiousness/spirituality.
4. We will test this hypothesis using correlational or regression analyses.

Hypothesis 5 (directional): The average trajectory of perceived PTG will indicate an increase in perceived PTG (5a), whereas there will be an average trajectory of decline in participants’ actual (prospectively measured) change in positive traits (5b), religiousness/spirituality (5c), and mental health (5d).
5. We will test this hypothesis using growth mixture modeling analyses.

Hypothesis 6 (directional): The following will be significant predictors of postdisaster psychological resilience (e.g., minimal depression and anxiety symptoms [scores of 4 or lower on the Patient Health Questionnaire–9 (PHQ-9) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder–7 (GAD-7)]): (6a) older age, (6b) male sex/gender, (6c) lower socioeconomic status, (6d) lower predisaster trauma exposure, (6e) lower predisaster personal suffering, (6f) higher predisaster positive traits, (6g) higher predisaster religiousness/spirituality, (6h) higher predisaster mental health, (6i) lower disaster-related resource loss, (6j) lower postdisaster perceived stress, and (6k) higher postdisaster social support.
6. We will test this hypothesis using multivariate logistic regression.

q18.value:
Most variables will not require any additional transformations. However, many of the sociodemographic predictors will be dummy-coded. Specifically, we will dummy code the following sociodemographic variables: 
1. Sex/gender: 0 = male, 1 = female or “other”
2. Sexual orientation: 0 = heterosexual (straight), 1 = homosexual (gay or lesbian), bisexual, or “other”
3. Race/ethnicity: 0 = White, 1 = Black/African-American, Asian/Pacific-Islander, Latina-o/Hispanic, American-Indian/Alaska-Native, Multiracial, or “other”
4. Marital status: 0 = “now married” or “living with partner (unmarried)”, 1 = never married, separated, divorced, or widowed
5. Religious affiliation (Christian vs. religious minority): 0 = Christian, 1 = Jewish, Muslim, Buddhist, Hindu, atheist or agnostic, nothing in particular, or “other”
6. Religious affiliation (religiously affiliated vs. unaffiliated): 0 = Christian, Jewish, Muslim, Buddhist, Hindu, or “other”, 1 = “atheist or agnostic” or “nothing in particular”

q19.value: We will be using one-tailed tests for each of our analyses. Because of the number of tests for each hypothesis, we will use Bonferonni corrections, which typically will require a p < .001 criterion to indicate significance.
